title: EverWatt Energy Efficiency Certification - For Food Service Engineers
subtitle: Certification for energy efficiency in restaurants and commercial kitchens
description: Validate your expertise in identifying and implementing energy efficiency measures for restaurants and commercial kitchens. This certification covers kitchen equipment, ventilation, refrigeration, and high heat loads.

questions.question: In commercial kitchens, what percentage of total energy is typically consumed by kitchen equipment and ventilation?
questions.explanation: Kitchen equipment and ventilation typically consume 60-70% of total energy in commercial kitchens. This includes cooking equipment, exhaust hoods, and make-up air systems.

questions.question: A restaurant has exhaust hoods that run at full speed continuously during operating hours. What efficiency opportunity exists?
questions.scenario: A restaurant has two exhaust hoods (Type I) that run at full speed continuously from 11 AM to 10 PM (11 hours/day). The hoods operate at full speed even during low-cooking periods.

options.text: Replace hoods with more efficient models
Install variable-speed controls to reduce fan speed during low-cooking periods

questions.explanation: Installing variable-speed controls (VFDs) on exhaust hood fans can reduce ventilation energy by 30-50% by reducing fan speed during low-cooking periods. This addresses the specific issue of continuous full-speed operation. Heat recovery is also valuable but requires more capital investment.

questions.question: What is the typical energy savings potential for kitchen exhaust hood variable-speed controls?
questions.explanation: Kitchen exhaust hood variable-speed controls typically yield 30-50% savings of ventilation energy. This is achieved by reducing fan speed during low-cooking periods while maintaining adequate ventilation for safety.

questions.question: A commercial kitchen has refrigeration equipment that runs continuously. What efficiency opportunity should you prioritize?

options.text: Optimize refrigeration: door gaskets, defrost schedules, temperature setpoints, evaporator fan controls

questions.explanation: Refrigeration optimization (door gaskets, defrost schedules, temperature setpoints, evaporator fan controls) can reduce refrigeration energy by 15-30%. This is typically more cost-effective than replacing all equipment and provides faster payback.

questions.question: What is the typical priority order for energy efficiency measures in commercial kitchens?

options.text: Building Envelope, HVAC, Lighting, Kitchen Equipment
Plug Loads, Lighting, HVAC, Kitchen Equipment

questions.explanation: For commercial kitchens, Kitchen Equipment/Ventilation is typically Very High priority (60-70% of energy). Refrigeration is High priority. HVAC is High priority. Lighting is Medium-High priority.
